block.p: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

As Afghanistan Struggles, One More Threat: AIDS H.I.V. and AIDS have quietly arrived in Afghanistan. It remains almost completely underground, as the government struggles with the help of American and NATO forces to rebuild the country. Surveys tell of 69 confirmed cases, but health officials warn that the incidence is certainly much higher. A1

Zimbabwe Blocks Critics' Travel Zimbabwe's crackdown on the nation's political opposition expanded to block foreign travel by leading government critics. Nelson Chamisa, the spokesman for the largest faction of the party, was severely beaten while en route to Harare's airport for a flight to Brussels, a party official, William Bango, told news services in Harare. A5

Mideast Policy Shows Fissures The first fractures surfaced in the Israeli and American approaches to the new Palestinian unity government, with Israel's cabinet voting overwhelmingly to boycott it, while the United States Consulate refused to rule out contacts with some individual Palestinian ministers. A7

Police Officials Held in Mexico Three high-ranking state police commanders and a former police chief were being held for questioning in the attempted killing of the Tabasco state secretary of public security, after hundreds of soldiers and federal agents raided the police headquarters the day before. A5

End of North Korea Impasse The United States and North Korea have resolved a standoff over North Korean funds frozen in a bank account in Macao, clearing the way for talks to focus on putting in place a nuclear disarmament accord, Chinese and American officials said. A5

Iraqi Official's Home Raided Iraqi security forces seized a large cache of weapons, detained a man with a sniper rifle and found four cars with traces of explosives during a raid on the home of a prominent Sunni Arab lawmaker this month, a senior Iraqi military spokesman said. A6
NATIONAL A8-13

Accounting by Shriners Raises Concerns An examination of the 135-year-old fraternal organization, the Shriners, yields a picture of lax accounting procedures and oversight under which money earmarked for the Shriners Hospitals for Children instead financed temple activities.
A1

Senator Wants Aides to Testify Senator Patrick J. Leahy, leading the inquiry into the dismissal of federal prosecutors, insisted that Karl Rove and other top aides to President Bush must testify publicly and under oath, setting up a confrontation between Congress and the White House over the fate of Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzalez.
A1

Lawsuit Centers on Adoption Olive F. Watson, a granddaughter of Thomas J. Watson, the founder of I.B.M., is involved in a lawsuit with her former same-sex partner, whom she adopted under Maine law. Her partner sued for part of a multimillion dollar inheritance after the couple separated, saying she was technically a grandchild of Mr. Watson.
A1

Uproar Over Unpaid Utility Bills Memphis Light, Gas and Water allowed a member of theMemphis city council to forgo paying thousands of dollars in overdue bills without having his power cut, and kept a list of local politicians used to prevent discontinuing their service if they failed to pay their utility bills. The situation has infuriated a city where nearly a quarter are poor and the local utility is publicly owned.
A8

Towns Put Climate on Agenda One-hundred-eighty of New Hampshire's 234 cities and towns are voting on a resolution asking the federal government to address climate change. Organizers also hope to use the effort to force presidential candidates to address climate change issues during the state's primary.
A8

Early Warnings of F.B.I. Lapses Before the Federal Bureau of Investigation publicly admitted that it had ignored its rules when demanding telephone and financial records about private citizens, a top official in the program warned the bureau about widespread lapses in 2005, his lawyer said.
NEW YORK/REGION B1-5

Atlantic City Rethinks Image as Revenues Fall Faced with competition from new casinos in Pennsylvania and slot machines at Yonkers Raceway in New York, Atlantic City casino operators, who have seen a fall in revenue for the year's first two months, are wagering large sums that they can transform the low-rent gambling factory into a world-class entertainment destination. A1

Robber Has Novel Defense Juan Medina, a man imprisoned at Rikers Island, claims he was working as an undercover operative and committed robbery with the full knowledge and cooperation of the United States Drug Enforcement Agency. The D.E.A., while admitting he was a paid confidential informant, has not come to his aid, and is helping prosecute him on charges of burglary, robbery and criminal possession of a weapon. B1
ARTS E1-8

Competition for N.P.R. Staple The New York public radio station WNYC is teaming up with the distributor Public Radio International to produce a national morning radio program that will compete with National Public Radio's long-running ''Morning Edition.'' The program is intended to expand the public radio audience by focusing on a younger, more multicultural listener than public radio typically draws. E3
OBITUARIES B6
Stuart Rosenberg A director of series television and theatrical films who captured the simmering anti-authoritarianism of the late 1960s in the Paul Newman prison drama ''Cool Hand Luke,'' he was 79.
B6
Jay Kennedy An editor in chief of King Features Syndicate who revived ''Prince Valiant'' and introduced the newspaper comic strips ''Curtis,'' ''Mutts'' and ''Zits,'' he was 50. B6
BUSINESS DAY C1-8
Cashing In on Video Ads Television networks like Nickelodeon are heavily promoting digital offerings, like online video, to advertisers this spring as video advertising becomes more lucrative.
C1

Overture to European Bank Barclays, one of Britain's largest banks, made an informal takeover approach for ABN Amro Holding, the largest bank in the Netherlands, which is under pressure to bolster its share price.
C1
Business Digest C2
EDITORIAL A14-15
Editorials: The Medicaid documentation mess; training workers for good jobs; still not fixing the Army Corps; Adam Cohen on the firing of United States attorneys.
Columns: Bob Herbert, Paul Krugman.
